articles.headline: Southern Cities Split With States on Social Issues
articles.snippet: Cities in the Deep South are increasingly at odds with their states on gay rights and other benchmarks, moving toward common ground with big cities on the coasts.
articles.abstract: Cities in the Deep South are increasingly at odds with their states on gay rights and other benchmarks, moving toward common ground with big cities on the coasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — It was not that long ago that Victoria Fortenberry figured she would mark her 18th birthday by getting on a bus and getting out of Mississippi. But here she was, blue-haired, tattooed and 19 years old, singing at a party for a new line of craft beer to a crowd that included her girlfriend.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Shrunken Citigroup Illustrates a Trend in Big U.S. Banks
articles.snippet: In the last seven years, Citigroup has sold more than 60 businesses, and its holdings have shrunk by $700 billion.
articles.abstract: In the last seven years, Citigroup has sold more than 60 businesses, and its holdings have shrunk by $700 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup became the nation’s first megabank some two decades ago by expanding into new businesses while pushing to knock down barriers that limited its size.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Fight to Impeach Brazil’s Leader Tears at Fabric of Daily Life
articles.snippet: Brazilian politics is a blood sport in the best of times, but the battle over whether to impeach President Dilma Rousseff is inflaming passions as never before.
articles.abstract: Brazilian politics is a blood sport in the best of times, but the battle over whether to impeach President Dilma Rousseff is inflaming passions as never before.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The wall, nearly a mile of corrugated metal, plunges down the center of the majestic lawn that faces Brazil’s National Congress, the modernist icon designed by Oscar Niemeyer.

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia Warns of Economic Fallout if Congress Passes 9/11 Bill
articles.snippet: The kingdom has bristled over a bill that would allow its government to be held responsible in American courts for any role in the Sept. 11 attacks.
articles.abstract: The kingdom has bristled over a bill that would allow its government to be held responsible in American courts for any role in the Sept. 11 attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia has told the Obama administration and members of Congress that it will sell off hundreds of billions of dollars’ worth of American assets held by the kingdom if Congress passes a bill that would allow the Saudi government to be held responsible in American courts for any role in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

articles.headline: Criticizing Israel, Bernie Sanders Highlights Split Among Jewish Democrats
articles.snippet: Mr. Sanders’s comments at Thursday’s Democratic debate buoyed critics of Benjamin Netanyahu’s government but worried pro-Israel Jewish groups.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sanders’s comments at Thursday’s Democratic debate buoyed critics of Benjamin Netanyahu’s government but worried pro-Israel Jewish groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the sort of question — Does Israel have a right to defend itself as it sees fit? — that had often caused candidates, especially those with designs on winning a primary in New York, to produce paeans to the strength of the Israeli-American relationship and a stream of pro-Israel orthodoxy.

articles.headline: Pope Francis Takes 12 Refugees Back to Vatican After Trip to Greece
articles.snippet: The pontiff visited Lesbos, the heart of Europe’s migrant crisis, asking for deeper sympathy at a moment when attitudes are hardening.
articles.abstract: The pontiff visited Lesbos, the heart of Europe’s migrant crisis, asking for deeper sympathy at a moment when attitudes are hardening.
articles.lead_paragraph: MYTILENE, Greece — Pope Francis made an emotional visit into the heart of Europe’s migrant crisis on Saturday and took 12 Muslim refugees from Syria, including six children, with him back to Rome aboard the papal plane.

articles.headline: In Cramped and Costly Bay Area, Cries to Build, Baby, Build
articles.snippet: An activist who calls her group BARF is pushing for more housing, pitting cranky homeowners and the political establishment against newcomers who want the region to make room for them, too.
articles.abstract: An activist who calls her group BARF is pushing for more housing, pitting cranky homeowners and the political establishment against newcomers who want the region to make room for them, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: San Francisco does not have enough places to live. Sonja Trauss, a local activist, thinks the city should tackle this problem by building more housing.

articles.headline: 272 Slaves Were Sold to Save Georgetown. What Does It Owe Their Descendants?
articles.snippet: In 1838, the Jesuit priests who ran the country’s top Catholic university needed money to keep it alive. Now comes the task of making amends.
articles.abstract: In 1838, the Jesuit priests who ran the country’s top Catholic university needed money to keep it alive. Now comes the task of making amends.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The human cargo was loaded on ships at a bustling wharf in the nation’s capital, destined for the plantations of the Deep South. Some slaves pleaded for rosaries as they were rounded up, praying for deliverance.

articles.headline: The Billionaire Who’s Building a Davos of His Own
articles.snippet: Philanthropists like Nicolas Berggruen are reshaping the landscape with smaller versions of the foundations established by Bill Gates and George Soros.
articles.abstract: Philanthropists like Nicolas Berggruen are reshaping the landscape with smaller versions of the foundations established by Bill Gates and George Soros.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a wood-paneled conference room at Stanford University, a score of scholars, many of them eminent and some from as far away as Johannesburg and Beijing, gathered last month to compare philosophical notions of hierarchy and equality.

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders’s Campaign Past Reveals Willingness to Play Hardball
articles.snippet: The Democratic presidential candidate with a reputation for being issues oriented has not shied away from mixing it up personally with opponents.
articles.abstract: The Democratic presidential candidate with a reputation for being issues oriented has not shied away from mixing it up personally with opponents.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the 1986 race for governor of Vermont, Bernie Sanders bristled at the popularity of the Democratic incumbent, Madeleine Kunin. Mr. Sanders, who was running against her as an independent, saw himself as a leader, and viewed Ms. Kunin as a lightweight.

articles.headline: In Campaign and Company, Ivanka Trump Has a Central Role
articles.snippet: Ms. Trump holds an exalted position in the family, in their company and even in her father’s campaign.
articles.abstract: Ms. Trump holds an exalted position in the family, in their company and even in her father’s campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a night to celebrate strong women. Amy Schumer was the host, Caitlyn Jenner was honored and the guests included Arianna Huffington, Madeleine Albright and the actress Reese Witherspoon.

articles.headline: Scenes of Ruin After Ecuador Earthquake Kills Hundreds
articles.snippet: More than 2,500 people were injured, the government said, in an earthquake that devastated a large swath of the Ecuadorean coast.
articles.abstract: More than 2,500 people were injured, the government said, in an earthquake that devastated a large swath of the Ecuadorean coast.
articles.lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — The strongest earthquake to strike Ecuador in decades left the Andean nation traumatized on Sunday, with collapsed buildings in a swath of destruction stretching hundreds of miles.
articles.byline: By Maggy Ayala and Nicholas Casey

articles.headline: In Doha, Major Oil Exporters Fail to Agree on Production Freeze
articles.snippet: The move would have involved little sacrifice on the part of oil producers, but they remained unable to reach an accord.
articles.abstract: The move would have involved little sacrifice on the part of oil producers, but they remained unable to reach an accord.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Officials from 18 oil-producing nations failed on Sunday to reach a deal to freeze oil production at current levels.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Ted Cruz’s Conservatism: The Pendulum Swings Consistently Right
articles.snippet: Mr. Cruz’s policy views over two decades suggest that he would be the most conservative presidential nominee in at least a half-century.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cruz’s policy views over two decades suggest that he would be the most conservative presidential nominee in at least a half-century.
articles.lead_paragraph: On perhaps the defining issue of the 2016 Republican primary, Senator Ted Cruz falls well to the right of Ronald Reagan, who supported granting legal status to millions of undocumented immigrants.

articles.headline: Brazil’s Lower House of Congress Votes for Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff
articles.snippet: The vote sends the case to the Senate, which will decide whether to hold a trial on charges that the president illegally used money from state-owned banks.
articles.abstract: The vote sends the case to the Senate, which will decide whether to hold a trial on charges that the president illegally used money from state-owned banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — Brazilian legislators voted on Sunday night to approve impeachment of Dilma Rousseff, the nation’s first female president, whose tenure has been buffeted by a dizzying corruption scandal, a shrinking economy and spreading disillusionment.

articles.headline: Tech Companies Face Greater Scrutiny for Paying Workers With Stock
articles.snippet: Stock-based compensation is largely unquestioned during boom periods, but tech companies’ rocky performance this year is prompting a closer look.
articles.abstract: Stock-based compensation is largely unquestioned during boom periods, but tech companies’ rocky performance this year is prompting a closer look.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For the last few years, LinkedIn, the professional social networking company, has doled out increasingly large amounts of stock to pay its workers.

articles.headline: Wall Street Veterans Bet on Low-Income Home Buyers
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs alumni are reselling foreclosed homes to people who didn’t qualify for traditional mortgages. Many of the transactions end in eviction.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs alumni are reselling foreclosed homes to people who didn’t qualify for traditional mortgages. Many of the transactions end in eviction.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the head of Goldman Sachs’s mortgage department, Daniel Sparks helped make the bank more than a billion dollars betting against the market as housing prices began to crash in 2007.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Found Alive, Soldiers Are Told: You Owe Us for Burials
articles.snippet: The families of two Afghan men experienced the trauma of their deaths, the joy of hearing they were alive, then the shock of a government demand that it get its money back.
articles.abstract: The families of two Afghan men experienced the trauma of their deaths, the joy of hearing they were alive, then the shock of a government demand that it get its money back.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEHSUD, Afghanistan — The first time Noor ul-Haq died, his Afghan Army outpost was completely cut off by the Taliban on a bleak southern battleground. Hundreds of insurgent fighters swept in, and all that was left for the government to do was ship the corpses home.

articles.headline: Media Websites Battle Faltering Ad Revenue and Traffic
articles.snippet: Changes in technology like ad blocking, and the dominance of platforms like Facebook leave many publishers unsure of how they will make money.
articles.abstract: Changes in technology like ad blocking, and the dominance of platforms like Facebook leave many publishers unsure of how they will make money.
articles.lead_paragraph: The business of online news has never been forgiving. But in recent weeks, what had been a simmering worry among publishers has turned into borderline panic.

articles.headline: For News Outlets Squeezed From the Middle, It’s Bend or Bust
articles.snippet: Traditional media companies face the increasingly daunting task of hooking already-inundated audiences, but they also have more tools than ever to lure them.
articles.abstract: Traditional media companies face the increasingly daunting task of hooking already-inundated audiences, but they also have more tools than ever to lure them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, a couple of inventive young go-getters at BuzzFeed tied enough rubber bands around the center of a watermelon to make it explode. Nearly a million people watched the giant berry burst on Facebook Live. It racked up more than 10 million views in the days that followed.

articles.headline: On Crime Bill and the Clintons, Young Blacks Clash With Parents
articles.snippet: Young African-Americans are challenging Clinton-era policies on crime, diverging from their elders who enthusiastically support Hillary Clinton and the former president.
articles.abstract: Young African-Americans are challenging Clinton-era policies on crime, diverging from their elders who enthusiastically support Hillary Clinton and the former president.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rufus Farmer, 33, was tired of all the ways he saw black men being mistreated by the nation’s law enforcement system — from the police officer who once berated him for crossing the street to the mandatory prison sentences that sent so many of his peers away.

articles.headline: Volatility Returns to Oil Market After OPEC Deal Fails
articles.snippet: After plunging in Asia, prices recovered somewhat in Europe, as traders weighed the breakdown of a summit meeting against an energy strike in Kuwait.
articles.abstract: After plunging in Asia, prices recovered somewhat in Europe, as traders weighed the breakdown of a summit meeting against an energy strike in Kuwait.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s back to Square 1 for the oil markets.

articles.headline: Obama Immigration Plan Seems to Divide Supreme Court
articles.snippet: During an extended argument, the justices occasionally paused to acknowledge realities outside the courtroom in connection with the president’s plan to shield millions from deportation.
articles.abstract: During an extended argument, the justices occasionally paused to acknowledge realities outside the courtroom in connection with the president’s plan to shield millions from deportation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday seemed sharply divided during an extended argument over a challenge to President Obama’s plan that would shield millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation and allow them to work in the country legally.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Avoiding the Dreaded Middle Seat May Now Cost You
articles.snippet: As planes fly a record capacity and try to squeeze in more passengers, it is becoming more difficult and costly to secure an aisle or window seat.
articles.abstract: As planes fly a record capacity and try to squeeze in more passengers, it is becoming more difficult and costly to secure an aisle or window seat.
articles.lead_paragraph: As flying goes, the only thing more uncomfortable than sitting next to a couple having a spat on an airplane, Maury Rogoff learned, is sitting between that couple — especially when one partner prefers bare feet.

articles.headline: Earthquake Leaves a Trail of Destruction in Ecuador
articles.snippet: Rescuers are still digging through the rubble from Saturday’s magnitude 7.8 quake, the strongest to strike Ecuador in decades.
articles.abstract: Rescuers are still digging through the rubble from Saturday’s magnitude 7.8 quake, the strongest to strike Ecuador in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTOVIEJO, Ecuador — The rumbling had ended and the rubble had settled, and Manuel Zambrano, 21, took stock of his situation: Somehow, he was alive.
articles.byline: By Maggy Ayala and Kirk Semple
